claim.body: further comprising: a dosimetry system that is configured to measure the beam current or density of the ion beam; and a beam diagnosis system configured to incrementally introduce the injected neutral gas into the ion implantation system according to the measured beam current or density.
claim.claim-text: 2. The ion implantation system of claim 1 , further comprising: a dosimetry system that is configured to measure the beam current or density of the ion beam; and a beam diagnosis system configured to incrementally introduce the injected neutral gas into the ion implantation system according to the measured beam current or density.

claim.body: the dosimetry system comprises a faraday cup proximate to the end station configured to measure the beam current or density of the ion beam.
claim.claim-text: 3. The ion implantation system of claim 2 , wherein the dosimetry system comprises a faraday cup proximate to the end station configured to measure the beam current or density of the ion beam.

claim.body: the dosimetry system comprises a profiler including a current density sensor configured to move along a scan path.

claim.body: a controller connected to a gas source, wherein the controller is configured to control the flow of injected neutral gas from the gas source, and deliver the injected gas to the inlet over a particular range of flow rates.

claim.body: the magnetic field comprises a variable magnetic field configured to scan the ion beam along a scan path.
claim.claim-text: 6. The ion implantation system of claim 5 , wherein the magnetic field comprises a variable magnetic field configured to scan the ion beam along a scan path.

claim.body: the controller is configured to incrementally insert an amount of injected neutral gas into the magnetic scanning element region to minimize a change in a measured beam current between different positions along the scan path.
claim.claim-text: 7. The ion implantation system of claim 6 , wherein the controller is configured to incrementally insert an amount of injected neutral gas into the magnetic scanning element region to minimize a change in a measured beam current between different positions along the scan path.

claim.body: the injected neutral gas comprises Argon or Xenon.

claim.body: the magnetic field is configured to substantially hold the ion beam at a single position.

claim.body: the controller is configured to incrementally insert an amount of injected neutral gas into the magnetic scanning element region to achieve a desired change in a measured beam current or density of the ion beam at the single position.

The ion implantation system of claim 9 , wherein the controller is configured to incrementally insert an amount of injected neutral gas into the magnetic scanning element region to achieve a desired change in a measured beam current or density of the ion beam at the single position.

claim.body: the injected neutral gas comprises an inert gas.

claim.body: the injected neutral gas increases a gas pressure in the magnetic scanning element.
claim.claim-text: 13. The ion implantation system of claim 1 , wherein the injected neutral gas increases a gas pressure in the magnetic scanning element.

claim.body: an ion implantation system, comprising: a magnetic scanner region comprising a first magnetic pole and a second magnetic pole configured to produce a magnetic field in an ion beam path; and an inlet configured to introduce an injected neutral gas into the ion implantation system to raise a gas pressure in the ion beam path and to enhance a current of an ion beam subjected to the magnetic field thereby effectively minimizing a zero field effect on the ion beam.
claim.claim-text: 14. A magnetic scanner for an ion implantation system, comprising: a magnetic scanner region comprising a first magnetic pole and a second magnetic pole configured to produce a magnetic field in an ion beam path; and an inlet configured to introduce an injected neutral gas into the ion implantation system to raise a gas pressure in the ion beam path and to enhance a current of an ion beam subjected to the magnetic field thereby effectively minimizing a zero field effect on the ion beam.

claim.body: the ion beam comprises an ion pencil beam running along a beam path and having a trajectory that is modified into a ribbon beam as it passes through the magnetic field.
claim.claim-text: 15. The magnetic scanner of claim 14 , wherein the ion beam comprises an ion pencil beam running along a beam path and having a trajectory that is modified into a ribbon beam as it passes through the magnetic field.

claim.body: the injected neutral gas comprises an inert gas.
claim.claim-text: 16. The magnetic scanner of claim 14 , wherein the injected neutral gas comprises an inert gas.

claim.body: the injected neutral gas is inserted directly into the scanning region at an inlet.
claim.claim-text: 17. The magnetic scanner of claim 14 , wherein the injected neutral gas is inserted directly into the scanning region at an inlet.

claim.body: a controller, connected to a gas source, configured to provide the injected neutral gas to the magnetic scanner region or a region proximate thereto, wherein the controller is configured to measure or control the injected neutral gas from the gas source, and deliver it to the inlet over a particular range of flow rates.
claim.claim-text: 18. The magnetic scanner of claim 14 , further comprising a controller, connected to a gas source, configured to provide the injected neutral gas to the magnetic scanner region or a region proximate thereto, wherein the controller is configured to measure or control the injected neutral gas from the gas source, and deliver it to the inlet over a particular range of flow rates.

claim.body: the magnetic field is configured to substantially hold the ion beam at a single position.

claim.body: the controller is configured to incrementally insert an amount of injected neutral gas into the magnetic scanner region or a region proximate thereto to achieve a desired change in a measured beam current or density of the ion beam at the single position.
claim.claim-text: 23. The magnetic scanner of claim 22 , wherein the controller is configured to incrementally insert an amount of injected neutral gas into the magnetic scanner region or a region proximate thereto to achieve a desired change in a measured beam current or density of the ion beam at the single position.

claim.body: uniformity of magnetically scanned ion beams in an ion implantation system, comprising: forming vacuum having a pressure in a magnetic scanning region of the ion implantation system; magnetically scanning an ion beam having a beam current or density across a scan path at a scan rate; and adding an injected neutral gas to the ion implantation system to provide a uniformity of the beam current of the magnetic ion beam over the scan path, thereby effectively mitigating a zero field effect, wherein the injected neutral gas is added according to a measured beam current signal resulting in an increase of the pressure in the magnetic scanning region.
claim.claim-text: 24. A method for improving uniformity of magnetically scanned ion beams in an ion implantation system, comprising: forming vacuum having a pressure in a magnetic scanning region of the ion implantation system; magnetically scanning an ion beam having a beam current or density across a scan path at a scan rate; and adding an injected neutral gas to the ion implantation system to provide a uniformity of the beam current of the magnetic ion beam over the scan path, thereby effectively mitigating a zero field effect, wherein the injected neutral gas is added according to a measured beam current signal resulting in an increase of the pressure in the magnetic scanning region.

claim.body: the beam current signal as the ion beam is scanned across the scan path.
claim.claim-text: 25. The method of claim 24 , further comprising measuring the beam current signal as the ion beam is scanned across the scan path.

claim.body: the beam current signal is measured by a faraday cup.
claim.claim-text: 26. The method of claim 25 , wherein the beam current signal is measured by a faraday cup.

claim.body: the beam current signal is measured by a profiler configured to move along the scan path.
claim.claim-text: 27. The method of claim 25 , wherein the beam current signal is measured by a profiler configured to move along the scan path.

claim.body: the injected neutral gas based on the measured beam current signal until the zero field effect is no longer measured.
claim.transPhrase: , further comprising incrementally adding or adjusting
claim.claim-text: 28. The method of claim 25 , further comprising incrementally adding or adjusting the injected neutral gas based on the measured beam current signal until the zero field effect is no longer measured.

claim.body: correcting for additional non-uniformities in the ion beam.
claim.claim-text: 29. The method of claim 24 , further comprising correcting for additional non-uniformities in the ion beam.

claim.body: the injected neutral gas comprises an inert gas.
claim.claim-text: 30. The method of claim 24 , wherein the injected neutral gas comprises an inert gas.

claim.body: the injected neutral gas comprises Argon or Xenon.
claim.claim-text: 31. The method of claim 30 , wherein the injected neutral gas comprises Argon or Xenon.

claim.body: the injected neutral gas is added by a controller connected to a gas source, wherein the controller is configured to measure and control the injected neutral gas from the gas source, and deliver it to the magnetic scanning region or a region proximate thereto over a particular range of flow rates.
claim.claim-text: 32. The method of claim 24 , wherein the injected neutral gas is added by a controller connected to a gas source, wherein the controller is configured to measure and control the injected neutral gas from the gas source, and deliver it to the magnetic scanning region or a region proximate thereto over a particular range of flow rates.

claim.body: uniformity of magnetically scanned ion beams in an ion implantation system, comprising: forming vacuum having a pressure in a magnetic scanning region of the ion implantation system; subjecting an ion beam having a beam current or density to a magnetic field forcing the ion beam to a substantially constant position; and adding an injected neutral gas to the ion implantation system to increase the beam current of the ion beam to a predetermined value configured to effectively mitigate a zero field effect, wherein the injected neutral gas is added according to a measured beam current signal resulting in an increase of the pressure in the magnetic scanning region.
claim.claim-text: 33. A method for improving uniformity of magnetically scanned ion beams in an ion implantation system, comprising: forming vacuum having a pressure in a magnetic scanning region of the ion implantation system; subjecting an ion beam having a beam current or density to a magnetic field forcing the ion beam to a substantially constant position; and adding an injected neutral gas to the ion implantation system to increase the beam current of the ion beam to a predetermined value configured to effectively mitigate a zero field effect, wherein the injected neutral gas is added according to a measured beam current signal resulting in an increase of the pressure in the magnetic scanning region.

claim.body: the beam current signal is measured by a faraday cup.
claim.claim-text: 34. The method of claim 33 , wherein the beam current signal is measured by a faraday cup.

claim.body: the beam current signal is measured by a profiler configured to move along the scan path.
claim.claim-text: 35. The method of claim 33 , wherein the beam current signal is measured by a profiler configured to move along the scan path.
